title: How to Make Saltimbocca

steps.headline: Purchase 6 cuts of veal scaloppine or 6 thinly cut chicken breasts.
steps.description: No matter which meet you choose, ask your butcher to cut them thin, if possible. You can also thin them yourself at home, but this step will save some time and effort. Scaloppine is also known as a veal cutlet, just with a more specific name. Both chicken and veal are used for saltimbocca, but the more traditional recipes are veal-based.

steps.headline: Cover the cutlets with plastic wrap and flatten to 1/4" (.6cm).
steps.description: Flatten the cuts evenly with a meat mallet or rolling pin. If the cutlets were cut thin by a butcher you should still take this step to lightly tenderize the meat.

steps.headline: Place one sage leaf on top of each cutlet.
steps.description: Fresh sage is always best. If the leaves are large, about the size of your index finger, then one leaf is fine. You can use 2-3 smaller leaves as well.

steps.headline: Lay a slice of prosciutto on top of the sage leaf.
steps.description: Pound the cutlets a few more times to secure the prosciutto and sage to the cut of meat.

steps.headline: Use 1-2 toothpicks to hold everything together.
steps.description: The best way to do this is by weaving the toothpick up and down through the prosciutto and veal/chicken. Note that some chefs skip this step, opting to be careful flipping and turning the meat as it cooks. For restaurant-quality looks, however, the toothpick is a must.

steps.headline: Place the flour in a shallow dish and season liberally with salt and pepper.
steps.description: A tablespoon of each is a decent start, but you can season the flour with as much salt and pepper as you prefer. Use a fork to mix it evenly into the flour.

steps.headline: Dredge the front and back of the meat with flour.
steps.description: Simply dip both sides of the meat into the flour, aiming for a light, even coat on the entire thing. Make sure the prosciutto is covered as well.

steps.headline: Heat 3 tablespoons of butter in a frying pan on medium-high heat.
steps.description: You can replace the butter with olive oil, but the traditional dish uses butter. Save one tablespoon of butter for later when making the sauce.

steps.headline: Cook 1-2 of the floured cutlets in the pan, prosciutto side down, for three minutes.
steps.description: When you flip the meat over the prosciutto should be browned and crisp. Do not crowd the pan, as this rapidly decreases the heat and prevents crisping. 1-2 pieces at a time is enough.

steps.headline: Flip and cook the second side for two minutes, until the center is no longer pink.
steps.description: If you're cooking multiple pieces separately, set aside the finished pieces and tent with foil to keep it warm. Then repeat with the next batch of saltimbocca.

steps.headline: Remove the chicken from the pan and add the white wine.
steps.description: Use a wooden spoon or spatula to scrape up all the browned and cooked bits on the bottom of the pan. They'll be loosened from the pan once the white wine hits. This is called deglazing.

steps.headline: Add the chicken or veal stock and simmer until the sauce is about one-third it's original amount.
steps.description: Simmering the sauce develops the flavors and thickens it up, making it easier to serve and eat.

steps.headline: Melt 1 tablespoon of butter into the sauce and stir.
steps.description: This will add a light creaminess to the sauce, but you can skip the step if you're feeling health conscience. Alternatively, add a dash of olive oil.

steps.headline: Spoon the sauce over your chicken and serve immediately.
steps.description: The dish is perfect right off the stovetop, as it doesn't take long to cook and gets a splash of heat from the fresh sauce. Enjoy with sprinkled parsley, Parmesan, or both. Be sure to remove the toothpicks before serving! Pair with pasta, gnocchi, or fresh bread to complete a simple meal.

steps.headline: Preheat your oven to 250F/120C.
steps.description: This will keep your meat warm as you're working through multiple batches of browning. It also allows you to quickly crisp the prosciutto later on.

steps.headline: Flatten your chicken or veal cutlets to roughly 1/4" (.6cm) thickness.
steps.description: If the butcher hasn't already cut them thin for you, use a meat pounder or rolling pin to flatten the meat. It needs to be thin in order to cook quickly and crisply. To prevent messes and splatter, cover your meat in plastic wrap before flattening it.

steps.headline: Heat half the butter in a sauce-pan on medium heat.
steps.description: Once it's completely melted and starting to froth, move on. You do not want to cook six pieces of chicken in the same pan, so save the rest for your second batch.

steps.headline: Cook about half the meat for two minutes on each side, until browned.
steps.description: It shoudln't take long, especially since your meat is so thin. Flip the cutlets once so that both sides are equally cooked.

steps.headline: Transfer the cooked chicken to a baking sheet and place in the hot oven.
steps.description: This will keep the meat hot as you finish the second batch.

steps.headline: Add more butter and cook the remaining meat.
steps.description: Remember, it only needs about 2 minutes on each side to get browned. When the chicken is all done, leave the stove on -- you'll need it for the sauce.

steps.headline: Place the cooked meat on a baking sheet and top each piece with prosciutto and fresh sage.
steps.description: Remove the other half of chicken from the oven and place 1-3 sage leaves over the meat. Cover with prosciutto as well.

steps.headline: Turn the oven up to broil.
steps.description: While waiting for the oven to heat you can get started on your pan sauce.

steps.headline: Add one cup (240ml) of white wine to the pan you cooked the meat with and scrape up any bits on the bottom.
steps.description: Once the cold wine hits the pan it will loosen any burned or browned bits. Stir them into the sauce and let everything simmer. The oven should still be heating up.

steps.headline: Pour any juice from the backing sheet into the sauce, then put the chicken in the oven.
steps.description: Keep your eye on it -- broiling shouldn't take too long. Don't worry yet if the oven isn't quite up to temperature. The point here is to brown the prosciutto, not cook the chicken or veal, so it doesn't have to be broil temperature just yet.

steps.headline: Lower the heat of the sauce to a simmer and add 1 tablespoon butter.
steps.description: Once the butter is melted, simply let the sauce keep cooking until it is ready to serve. You should have about one-third of the liquid you started with when you added the wine.

steps.headline: Broil your saltimbocca for 1-3 minutes, until prosciutto is crispy.
steps.description: This is mostly up to you. Note that broiling is very, very quick, so keep your eyes peeled. Meanwhile, the sauce should still be simmering, the liquid slowly reducing. If it is almost dry, add a little more wine to the pan.

steps.headline: Remove the meat and garnish with sauce, serving immediately.
steps.description: Once the broiler is off, pour some sauce over the meat and serve hot. You can garnish with fresh parsley or Parmesan, if desired. Lemon wedges are also common.

steps.headline: Melt Fontina cheese on the tops of the cutlets for a decadent dinner.
steps.description: This works particularly well for the quick recipe, as it already uses the broiler. Either way, this is an easy variation. Once the cooking is done and before pouring the sauce on top of each saltimbocca, top each cutlet with a piece of fontina cheese. Place each cutlet on a baking sheet and broil for 2-3 minutes, until cheese is melted. Top with one more piece of sage and enjoy.

steps.headline: Add shallots, mushrooms, and/or garlic to your sauce for a more robust flavor.
steps.description: After flipping the final cutlet of meat, toss in 2-3 minced shallots, 1/2 pound of sliced mushrooms, and/or 2-3 minced garlic cloves into the pan. Let them cook for one minute, until fragrant, then add the wine, proceeding like normal from here to create your sauce. Remember to take the chicken or veal out, too! If timed right, it should finish cooking right before your add the wine.

steps.headline: Plate the saltimbocca on a bed of wilted spinach for a traditional meal.
steps.description: This is a classic Italian paring, and it is easy to accomplish. Simply heat up 2 tablespoons butter or olive oil in a pan. If desired, add half of a finely chopped onion and 2-3 minced cloves of garlic, cooking for 1 minute. Then add a large bunch of spinach, enough to fill up the whole pan. Cook for 1-2 minutes, until soft and about half it's original size, stirring regularly.

steps.headline: Marinate the chicken ahead of time for more flavor options.
steps.description:
Veal is naturally flavorful, and needs little more than a bit of salt and pepper to truly shine. Chicken, on the other hand, often needs a little more "oomph." To marinate it, massage the following ingredients into the chicken and let it sit at room temperature for an hour, or 2-3 hours in the fridge. Salt and pepper, to taste
1/4 (60ml) cup olive oil
1 tablespoon (30ml) chopped or dried sage
1 teaspoon (5ml) red pepper flakes
2 cloves garlic pieces, smashed into a paste.

steps.headline: Fry your sage leaves in olive oil for a traditional and savory garnish.
steps.description: This is a classic Italian touch for professional dishes. Have a slotted spoon handy and heat up 1 cup (240ml) olive oil in a small pan on medium heat. Once the oil is shimmering, add the sage and cook for only 30 seconds. Remove and pat dry with paper towels, then place 1-2 leaves on the finished saltimbocca when it is done.

steps.headline: Finished.

Then repeat with the next batch of saltimbocca. Remove the chicken from the pan and add the white wine.
